children.subject: For quantitative finance, statistical theory from 126 is almost surely more important. I think it kind of depends on your purpose. While I haven't taken it, having helped friends with 188 homework makes me believe 188 may present some AI material (heuristics, game theory etc.) that isn't used so much nowadays since statistical machine learning/deep learning is the dominant form of "AI" (personally dont like that name designation) nowadays due to it being much easier to get results with. To prepare for statistical learning theory classes like 189 126 is definitely more useful, (since it teaches the Kalman filter, MLE , MAP , EM algorithm etc.), but if you want an overview of AI from a wholistic perspective without going too heavy in depth 188 would still be nice to take

I think 126 will serve you better. For 189 or any ML research, it's good to have the fundamentals, which includes 126. For quant, you would almost definitely want 126 over 188, since most quant interviews that I know of are probability/brain-teaser questions.

history.content:
I am debating between CS188 and EE126 next semester and was wondering if I could get some advice. I have roughly equivalent background in probability/calculus and programming/python (I do plan to eventually take both courses). I hope to eventually get involved in ML and I plan to take CS189 in Fall 2019 and I hear that it's incredibly beneficial to take EE126 before CS189. However, I feel like AI is an in demand skill and learning it earlier will help me out.  

I was wondering which course would be more useful at the moment if I want to get research positions (CS related, preferably ML) and/or a Quant internships as well as how difficult each course is.
history.subject: CS188 vs EE126
